content: Added "write answer" to stub generator.

While I'm not fond of the loop detection on easy puzzle, some testcases already required it so I took the liberty to add 2 edge testcases ("Loop detection"). I saw a lot of solutions assuming that the loop was on the starting point while it wasn't stated in the statement. Feel free to put back your python solution once you solved the new testcases since I had to update it.

After receiving two comments on my solution from one year ago about how I wouldn't pass all possible scenarios, I spent some time making changes to my code.

While doing that, it became clear to me that the test cases of this puzzle are not very good at all! I have found 4 shortcomings (2 of which Caduchon and suffer3d pointed out already as a comment on my published C++ solution):
* the direction matters when coming across the same spot as before - see test case 1
* the starting position doesn't have to be the beginning of a loop (and it might not even be revisited at all) - see test case 2
* with large n in all test cases, there are always loops - so, there should be a test case with something like n=2 as well (for example, FaizanRizvi’s published C++ solution throws an error for such cases) – see test case 3
* turning more than once on one spot is possible – see test case 4

Test cases (and validators) like mine below should definitely be added soon so imperfect solutions won't be able to pass any longer.

@BLANC: If you would incorporate these changes it'd be great. If nothing changes in the next days, I'll do it myself. :) If anyone has further thoughts about this or prove my test cases wrong, please say so. Thanks!

test case 1:
6 5
15
######
##...#
#.O#.#
#....#
######
expected output: 2 3

test case 2:
5 5
13
#####
#...#
#.#.#
#...#
#O###
expected output: 3 1

test case 3:
4 4
2
####
#..#
#O.#
####
expected output: 2 1

test case 4:
5 5
4
#####
#...#
#.#.#
#...#
##O##
expected solution: 1 3
loop detection and big int on a easy one. Are you all crazy ?

Most important issue I see is that you lack some interesting and I think also important test cases:
- a long loop that does not pass through the starting position;
- no loop but passing again though the starting position (this time in a horizontal direction)

There are a lot of solutions already posted that would fail such cases because of their naive loop detection.

Also, a test case with a size small enough to solve by hand is usually better for an example and first test case. It would help to demonstrate the "(on same operation)" thing which I still think is unclear as it is worded now.

Lastly, it does not occur in the current test cases but it might be worth consideration and clarification, what if there is an obstacle both in front and right of the robot?

I just changed 2 little things :
* On the sentence "When the robot ...". I add "(on same operation)" (just to clarify that rotation is not an operation)
* I add "(separated by a space)" on the output explanation

Thx for puzzle !

I've:
- simplified the English a bit
- replaced the ASCII with the more visually-appealing ones
- swapped tests and validators for 3, 4, 5 (the validator was much larger every time)
And approved.

https://prnt.sc/oefrk8
Is that normal or do I lack some fancy unicode here?

It is indeed similar to Bender 1, but the fact that you cannot just simulate blindly for high repeat count makes it different and interesting as a medium puzzle.

I clarified by adding in the constraints that the obstacles guarantee the robot cannot leave the map.

"Repeat it"? Repeat what?

Additionally, your "robot program" is more like a state machine, it just *is*, it doesn't really execute itself, let alone a specific number of times.

Could be easier to just count the number of *moves*

I'd advice you to change the characters you chose for representing the map, especially the empty spots. They are way easier to read like this for instance:
----#-------
--------#---
-----------#
---#O-------
---#--------
-------#----
-----------#
----#-------
(Even easier if the message allowed me to format it correctly ahah)

10**18 makes this much harder in languages that don't support 64bit integers (javascript). I'd recommend reducing it to something that can work when stored in a double (2**53 maximum before accuracy is lost)

I am fine with the puzzle, much less with the story. My feeling is that the bold sentence is enough to state what is expected.  What happens when the bot hits the border of the map ? I guess it turns right too and you should explain that.

Before trying:

* the backstory seems a bit convoluted. There are much simpler reasons for wanting to find the end of a robot's path than "the education programme made it so".
* a bit more confusion: "the students programmed the robot" vs "your program" (nowhere does it say you must write a program to find the answer)
* D for start? :p
* didn't find where you specified if x was horizontal or vertical
* that's not really ascii art (thank god!)

Apart from that, this is very similar to one of the bender puzzles.
The real question is, why does the teacher need to intercept the robot when its batteries die? If the batte​ries die, the robot can't move, right?

Hello, I would be happy to receive your advice to improve this puzzle using your recommendations through your comments. In addition, I would like to ask you again for your help on several points:
-Advise me to fix the difficulty of the puzzle 
-Check that the tests and validators are consistent 
-Check the reliability of the answers
-Suggest some improvements;)
Thank you for your participation

I admit I didn't really spend my time on the story, you can imagine that when the robot is at rest it recharges with solar energy and will, therefore, we must enjoy the moment of respite. I will make the right change; ). Thanks
Specifically, https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/bender-episode-1

Hi I'm glad you like the puzzle, but if you have any suggestions for stating it I want to know them well, on the other hand, I don't need to explain what happens when the robot leaves, because as indicated in the constrained part, it never leaves.
Hello, thank you for your remark, I will try to make this change as soon as possible

Hi, thank you for your advice, I made this choice in order to have the columns aligned:
----------
##--------
---------- 
--------##
which is problematic, while with this type of writing the columns are a little more aligned.
OOOOOOOOOO
ZZOOOOOOOO
OOOOOOOOOO
OOOOOOOOZZ
Thank you for your advice, I tried to apply it, tell me if it suits you better now
Thank you for your help. ; )
Which part, the exponent?
I fixed it, testing welcome :)
Wow, thank you very much for your work.
Cool thanks for your help.
Hello, I thank you for your feedback, and I note your recommendations in order to implement them as soon as possible.
And so...? What do you want?

I always welcome advice from the community to help make my puzzles better. So I've added the tests and validators that you advised me. I hope I've done the necessary, let me know if it suits you.
Thanks for your feedback
thanks

Thanks for your quick reply! :)
The 4 additional test cases cover 4 different scenarios in my opinion so I hope people don't get frustrated when all their tests work but some validator doesn't...
So, one last thing to change is either:
* come up with a slightly different validator for all 4 cases mentioned above so that people can see in the test cases what issues their code might have
* a quick fix: switch test 7 and validator 7 because the current validator 7 is the only scenario in which the robot has to turn twice on the same spot and 3/4 published solutions in C++ that I tested against this case failed! It would be mean to not include this kind of issue in a visible test case, I think. ;)

I've taken the liberty of adding four more cases so that test cases and validators 6-9 now present edge cases and each test has a corresponding validator that is slightly different and covers the same scenario. Also, I've added "until there's no obstacle ahead anymore" into the problem statement to explicitly say the robot can turn more than once in the same spot and it counts as one operation.

I hope you're okay with these changes and I think the new test cases make it a little more challenging (maybe change difficulty to medium? - that's your choice; as you like :) ) while still being reasonable scenarios according to the puzzle statement. :D
Change the level to at least medium or change the tests. I don't care

So, several things:
- It is true that I hesitated to put this in medium but as you can see it is in easy, and yet the success rate is higher than 77%, so I deduce that it should not really cause any problems.
- Why did I put it in easy then? Quite simply because I made the rollercoaster puzzle which proposed to confront the optimization to succeed, I found it too bad that there was no simpler puzzle to tackle this theme.

RollerCoster is an HARD one so what is the problem with puting this one in medium. 

The success percentage has no meaning since most of real newbies won't even submit their code. 

At least put a word about this loop detection.
What you call loop detection is like pattern repetition I imagine.
The fact that one MUST detect a loop in order to cut the machine.
Yes, you're right, I'll make the change. Thank you.
The enumeration point at the start of the line
I see the same, it's a latin1 character. Maybe there's a more standard way to generate a bullet point?
Bender 1 had mandatory loop detection, which is more or less the same thing.

In Bender 1 I just tested if the number of steps was above 10 times the surface of the map :D (I guess 4 times should work, since there are 4 possible directions)

Here you need to precisely detect the cycle length to predict the final position. That part is similar to Roller Coaster, actually.
Shit. I overengineered my bender.
Much better!

Use backticks (`) to enclose your map. All characters have the same length in backticks. This will make the alignment in your post perfect. And don't worry about test cases since when displayed in the console, the alignment will be perfect too.

For the story, I would just state the problem. I have a robot, it behaves like this, it will perform a number of steps, compute where it is at the end of the journey. Basically all you need to say is already there, just make your statement leaner. It's just my two cents and others may disagree for perfectly valid reasons.

Yes, as you stated, it doesn't leave. But what does it do ? Implicitly, I would treat the border as an obstacle. I suggest that you explicitly state this.
Very well thank you I will make this modification to make it clearer, however by adding this useless information I am precisely afraid to overload it.

Hi, thank you for your remark, I will indeed make it less confusing. In addition, I will replace "D" by "S", remove ascii art and make some clarifications. On the other hand, the interest of this puzzle is not so much the movement on the map (as you already say there is Bender) but it is the optimization to process a lot of data) moreover it is something that I find interesting and not enough spread on CG. Finally, this puzzle is more accessible than Bender so it's a good compromise.

As far as I can remember, Bender has the optimization requirement too. More explicitly.

But indeed, this is more accessible.

JBM, I can't deny the fact that it is similar to Bender but despite having done this puzzle, I didn't have the same impression when I solved Bender and solved this puzzle. The card is just another "difficulty", it is especially how to process 10**18 given in the time allowed. That being said, I try to make every effort to solve the problems you handle.
How about infinite batteries, but you want to intercept it at a very specific time? (for whatever reason you'll have to come up with)
Hi, I finally got to change the instruction.
